Line 240: Line 240:
===Deaths===
===Deaths===
â
[[File:Ali Jawad al-Sheikh by Ahmad Nady.jpg|thumb|upright|Political cartoon of Ali Jawad al-Sheikh by [[Ahmad Nady]].]]
+
[[File:Ali Jawad al-Sheikh by Ahmad Nady.jpg|thumb|upright|Political cartoon of [[Ali Jawad al-Sheikh]] by [[Ahmad Nady]].]]
Bahrain's [[Ministry of Interior (Bahrain)|Interior Minister]], Sheikh Rashed bin Abdullah al-Khalifa, stated on 29 March that a total of twenty-four people had been killed in the protests. He said that four security officers, seven civilians and 13 protesters had perished in the weeks of unrest.<ref name="arabianbusiness.com"/> Two of the civilians were an Indian and a Bangladeshi. With the deaths of four detained protestors in custody between 3 and 12 April<ref name="aljazeera1">[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/04/201141220154357546.html Bahrain opposition figure 'dies in custody'] Retrieved 13 April 2011.</ref> the death toll reached 30 (when including the four police officers and one Saudi soldier killed<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/03/15/bahrain-state-of-emergency-saudi-soldier-killed_n_835832.html|title=Bahrain Declares State Of Emergency After Saudi Soldier Shot Dead|work=Huffington Post }}</ref>).<ref>[http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hjkBtBjjzr0PdgHCKrnX2R4CnldQ?docId=CNG.34b89149aa6e7d06680c9cf785978729.671 "Bahrain Activist Dies in Jail: Ministry"]. [[Agence France-Presse]] (via Google News). Retrieved 5 April 2011.</ref> Later, the Bahrain Center for Human Rights claimed on 14 April, that 31 protestors were killed since the start of the unrest,<ref>[[Staff writer]] (14 April 2011). [http://www.adnkronos.com/IGN/Aki/English/Security/Bahrain-Thirty-one-protesters-killed-600-arrested-since-February-group-says_311903716211.html "Bahrain: 'Thirty-One Protesters Killed, 600 Arrested', Since February, Group Says"]. [[Adnkronos]]. Retrieved 15 April 2011.</ref> which would make a total of 36 deaths.
Bahrain's [[Ministry of Interior (Bahrain)|Interior Minister]], Sheikh Rashed bin Abdullah al-Khalifa, stated on 29 March that a total of twenty-four people had been killed in the protests. He said that four security officers, seven civilians and 13 protesters had perished in the weeks of unrest.<ref name="arabianbusiness.com"/> Two of the civilians were an Indian and a Bangladeshi. With the deaths of four detained protestors in custody between 3 and 12 April<ref name="aljazeera1">[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/04/201141220154357546.html Bahrain opposition figure 'dies in custody'] Retrieved 13 April 2011.</ref> the death toll reached 30 (when including the four police officers and one Saudi soldier killed<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/03/15/bahrain-state-of-emergency-saudi-soldier-killed_n_835832.html|title=Bahrain Declares State Of Emergency After Saudi Soldier Shot Dead|work=Huffington Post }}</ref>).<ref>[http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hjkBtBjjzr0PdgHCKrnX2R4CnldQ?docId=CNG.34b89149aa6e7d06680c9cf785978729.671 "Bahrain Activist Dies in Jail: Ministry"]. [[Agence France-Presse]] (via Google News). Retrieved 5 April 2011.</ref> Later, the Bahrain Center for Human Rights claimed on 14 April, that 31 protestors were killed since the start of the unrest,<ref>[[Staff writer]] (14 April 2011). [http://www.adnkronos.com/IGN/Aki/English/Security/Bahrain-Thirty-one-protesters-killed-600-arrested-since-February-group-says_311903716211.html "Bahrain: 'Thirty-One Protesters Killed, 600 Arrested', Since February, Group Says"]. [[Adnkronos]]. Retrieved 15 April 2011.</ref> which would make a total of 36 deaths.
